Test Case Title: As a Nurse, I want to access digitized patient assessments and care plans so that I can efficiently review patient information and update vitals.
Step Action: the Nurse is logged into the Clinician Portal | the Nurse selects a patient
Step Expected: the system displays the digitized patient assessments and care plans
Epic: Digitize patient records and automate tracking.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to view patient documents and clinical information in an organized manner, so that I can efficiently manage patient care.
Step Action: I am logged into the clinician portal. | I select a patient.
Step Expected: I can view the patient's documents and clinical information in an organized format.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to view scanned documents associated with a patient, so that I can review their medical history and current condition.
Step Action: I am logged into the clinician portal and viewing a patient's record. | I navigate to the 'Documents' section of the patient's record.
Step Expected: I should see a list of scanned documents associated with the patient, including relevant metadata (e.g., date, document type).

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to view patient data in the clinician portal so that I can efficiently review patient information and make informed decisions.
Step Action: I am logged into the clinician portal as a Doctor. | I select a patient from the patient list.
Step Expected: I can view the patient's relevant documents and clinical information in an organized manner.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to quickly access and review patient data in an organized manner so that I can make informed decisions about patient care.
Step Action: I am logged into the Clinician Portal. | I search for a specific patient.
Step Expected: I can view the patient's relevant clinical information and documents in a clear and organized format.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to quickly access and review patient data in an organized manner so that I can make informed decisions about patient care.
Step Action: I am viewing a patient's record. | I navigate to different sections of the record (e.g., vitals, medications, reports).
Step Expected: The information loads quickly and is easy to understand.

Test Case Title: As a Patient, I want to check in to Day Health and specific sessions using a fingerprint scanner, so that I can easily verify my attendance.
Step Action: I am a patient at Day Health and have a scheduled session. | I use the Session App fingerprint scanner.
Step Expected: My attendance is recorded for Day Health and the specific session.

Test Case Title: As a system, I want to store previous states of all tables with all changes made to them so that data can be recovered and audited.
Step Action: The system is running and data is being modified | A change is made to any table in the database
Step Expected: The previous state of the table is stored along with the changes made.

Test Case Title: As a Patient, I want to sign in for the day so that my attendance is recorded.
Step Action: I am a patient at Day-Health | I use the fingerprint scanner
Step Expected: my attendance for the day is recorded in the system

Test Case Title: As a Patient, I want to sign out for the day so that my attendance is accurately recorded.
Step Action: I am a patient in the system. | I sign out for the day.
Step Expected: My sign-out time is stored in the system.

Test Case Title: As a Patient, I want to sign in for sessions so that my attendance is recorded.
Step Action: The patient is present at the session location. | The patient uses the fingerprint scanner to sign in.
Step Expected: The system records the patient's attendance for the session.

Test Case Title: As a Patient, I want to sign out for sessions so that my attendance is accurately recorded.
Step Action: I am a patient attending a session | I sign out using the fingerprint scanner
Step Expected: My sign-out time is stored in the system

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to store new documents in the database, so that patient information is readily available and up-to-date.
Step Action: I am a logged-in Clinician with appropriate write access. | I upload a new patient document (e.g., assessment, lab result).
Step Expected: The document is securely stored in the database and linked to the correct patient record.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to add a patient's care plan so that I can manage and track their treatment effectively.
Step Action: I am logged in as a Clinician and have selected a patient. | I enter the details of the patient's care plan, including goals, interventions, and schedule.
Step Expected: The care plan is stored in the system and associated with the patient's record.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to store patient care plans so that I can easily access and manage them within the system.
Step Action: The doctor is logged into the system. | The doctor creates or updates a patient's care plan.
Step Expected: The care plan is stored securely in the database, adhering to HIPAA regulations.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to track reviews of care plans so that I can ensure patient care plans are regularly evaluated and updated.
Step Action: A care plan exists for a patient | A doctor reviews the care plan
Step Expected: The system should record the review date and the doctor who performed the review.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to track approval of care plans so that I can ensure proper authorization and compliance.
Step Action: A care plan exists for a patient | The care plan is submitted for approval
Step Expected: The system should record the approval status, approver, and timestamp.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to store care plan updates and changes, so that I can maintain an accurate and up-to-date record of patient care.
Step Action: A care plan exists for a patient | The Doctor updates the care plan
Step Expected: The system stores the updated care plan and tracks the changes made.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to store tracks so that I can monitor patient progress over time.
Step Action: The system is running and a patient record is open. | I input track data (e.g., therapy session attendance, medication adherence).
Step Expected: The system stores the track data securely and associates it with the correct patient record.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to store classes so that I can manage patient schedules and track attendance.
Step Action: The clinician is logged into the system. | The clinician creates a new class with relevant details (name, time, date, location, instructor).
Step Expected: The system stores the class information in the database.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to store classes so that I can manage patient schedules and track attendance.
Step Action: A class exists in the system. | The clinician updates the class details (e.g., time, location, instructor).
Step Expected: The system updates the class information in the database.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to link patients to classes so that I can manage patient schedules and track participation.
Step Action: I am a clinician with appropriate privileges. | I attempt to link a patient to a class.
Step Expected: The system should allow me to associate the patient with the selected class.

Test Case Title: As a Nurse, I want to store schedules, so that I can manage patient appointments and staff availability.
Step Action: I am logged in as a Nurse. | I enter schedule information for patients and staff.
Step Expected: The system stores the schedule information in the database.

Test Case Title: As a user, I want to store sessions so that patient session data is recorded and accessible.
Step Action: The user has the appropriate permissions | The user inputs session data
Step Expected: The session data is stored securely in the system

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to store group notes for sessions so that I can easily track patient progress in group settings.
Step Action: A session exists in the system | I enter group notes for the session
Step Expected: The group notes are stored securely and associated with the session.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to store individual notes for sessions, so that I can track patient progress and tailor treatment plans effectively.
Step Action: A session exists for a patient | I enter notes related to the session
Step Expected: The notes are stored securely and associated with that specific session and patient, adhering to HIPAA regulations.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to track reviews of care plans so that I can ensure patients are receiving appropriate and timely care.
Step Action: A care plan exists for a patient. | A doctor reviews the care plan.
Step Expected: The system should record the review date and the doctor who performed the review.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to view the Assessment timeline so that I can easily track patient progress.
Step Action: I am logged into the system as a Doctor and viewing a patient's record. | I navigate to the Assessments section.
Step Expected: I should see a timeline displaying the patient's assessment history, including dates and key milestones, calculated automatically.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to calculate who is billable based on dates, so that the billing process can be streamlined and accurate.
Step Action: The system has patient data, session information, and billing rules. | I request to determine billable patients for a specific date range.
Step Expected: The system accurately calculates and displays a list of patients who are billable, based on the defined rules and available data.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to keep track of what claims have been sent for, so that I can efficiently manage billing and ensure accurate revenue cycle management.
Step Action: The system contains patient and session data. | A claim is submitted for a patient's session.
Step Expected: The system records the details of the claim, including patient, session, date, and services billed.

Test Case Title: As a User, I want to keep track of claims that have been accepted or denied so that I can manage billing effectively.
Step Action: The system has processed a claim | The claim is accepted or denied
Step Expected: The system should record the acceptance or denial status of the claim.

Test Case Title: As a system, I want to have stored procedures for calculations within the database so that data processing is efficient and consistent.
Step Action: The database is operational | A calculation is required
Step Expected: The appropriate stored procedure is executed

Test Case Title: As a system, I want to have stored procedures for calculations within the database so that data processing is efficient and consistent.
Step Action: A new calculation is needed | A developer creates a stored procedure
Step Expected: The stored procedure is stored in the database

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to view the audit history of patient documents and data, so that I can ensure data integrity and compliance.
Step Action: I am logged into the Clinician Portal as a Doctor. | I view a patient's record.
Step Expected: I can access a report showing the audit history of documents and data associated with that patient, including additions, changes, and deletions.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to view the audit history of patient documents and data, so that I can ensure data integrity and compliance.
Step Action: I am logged into the Clinician Portal as a Doctor. | I request an audit history report.
Step Expected: I can export the audit history in a standard format.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to see session information including facilitator information, time and scheduling, attendance, and group and individual notes, so that I can effectively review patient progress and session details.
Step Action: I am logged in as a Doctor and viewing a patient's record. | I select a particular session from the list of sessions.
Step Expected: I should be able to see Session information, including Facilitator information, Time and scheduling, Attendance, and Group and Individual notes.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to view session information including facilitator, time, scheduling, attendance, and notes, so that I can effectively review patient progress and plan future care.
Step Action: I am logged into the system as a Doctor and viewing a specific patient's page. | I navigate to the 'Sessions' section of the patient's page.
Step Expected: I should see a list of sessions, and upon selecting a session, I should be able to view details including Facilitator information, Time and scheduling, Attendance, and Group and Individual notes.

Test Case Title: As a Facilitator, I want to confirm session attendance taken through fingerprint scanner, so that I can ensure accurate records.
Step Action: I am a facilitator with medium experience with the system. | I access the session attendance records.
Step Expected: I can confirm the attendance taken through the fingerprint scanner.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to run a billing report so that I can track billing information.
Step Action: I am a Clinician and have access to the system. | I initiate the billing report function.
Step Expected: I can view and export a report containing billing information.

Test Case Title: As a user, I want to see a list of sessions in the portal so that I can easily find and access the sessions I need.
Step Action: I am logged into the portal. | I navigate to the sessions section.
Step Expected: I should see a list of all available sessions.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to view details of a specific session so that I can review patient progress and session outcomes.
Step Action: The user is logged in and viewing a list of sessions. | The user selects a particular session from the list.
Step Expected: The system displays detailed information about the selected session, including facilitator information, time and scheduling, attendance, and group/individual notes.

Test Case Title: As a user, I want to see session information so that I can review session details.
Step Action: I am viewing a list of sessions in the portal | I select a particular session
Step Expected: I should be able to see session information including facilitator information, time and scheduling, attendance, and group and individual notes.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to view Group and Individual notes for a session, so that I can understand the patient's progress and tailor treatment plans accordingly.
Step Action: I am logged into the Clinician Portal and viewing the details of a specific session. | I navigate to the 'Notes' section of the session details.
Step Expected: I should be able to see both Group and Individual notes recorded for the patient within that session.

Test Case Title: As a Nurse, I want to enter and view patient assessments, so that I can accurately document and monitor patient progress.
Step Action: I am logged into the system as a Nurse. | I navigate to a patient's record.
Step Expected: I can enter new assessment data (Nursing, Nutrition, Health Literacy, Care Management, Behavioral) and view existing assessments.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to view patient assessments including Nursing, Nutrition, Health Literacy, Care Management, and Behavioral Health, so that I can make informed decisions about patient care.
Step Action: I am logged into the system as a Doctor. | I view a patient's record.
Step Expected: I can see a section displaying patient assessments, including Nursing, Nutrition, Health Literacy, Care Management, and Behavioral Health assessments.

Test Case Title: As a Nurse, I want to enter and view patient assessments (Nursing, Nutrition, Health Literacy, Care Management, Behavioral) so that I can effectively contribute to the care plan process.
Step Action: I am logged into the system as a Nurse. | I access a patient's record.
Step Expected: I can view and enter assessments related to Nursing, Nutrition, Health Literacy, Care Management, and Behavioral aspects.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to perform care plan reviews so that I can ensure the patient's care plan is up-to-date and effective.
Step Action: I am a logged-in Clinician viewing a patient's record. | I initiate a care plan review.
Step Expected: I am able to access and review the patient's current care plan details.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to view a patient's care plan history, so that I can track changes and understand the patient's treatment progression.
Step Action: A patient has one or more care plans recorded in the system. | I navigate to the patient's record and select the option to view care plan history.
Step Expected: I should see a chronological list of all care plans for that patient, including the dates they were active.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to view a patient's care plan history, so that I can track changes and understand the patient's treatment progression.
Step Action: I am viewing a list of care plan history entries. | I select a specific care plan from the history.
Step Expected: I should be able to view the details of that care plan as it existed at that point in time.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to make updates or changes to a Care Plan so that the patient's care plan is current and accurate.
Step Action: a Care Plan exists for a patient | I make updates or changes to the Care Plan
Step Expected: the system should save the updates and changes to the Care Plan

Test Case Title: As a system administrator, I want the system to audit all data changes, so that I can track data modifications for compliance and security purposes.
Step Action: The system is running and a user modifies patient data or documents. | The user adds, changes, or deletes data.
Step Expected: The system logs the action, including the user, timestamp, and details of the change.

Test Case Title: As a system administrator, I want the system to audit all data changes, so that I can track data modifications for compliance and security purposes.
Step Action: I am a system administrator. | I request an audit report for a specific user or patient.
Step Expected: The system generates a report showing the auditing history, including additions, changes, and deletions.

Test Case Title: As a system administrator, I want the system to audit all data changes, so that I can track data modifications for compliance and security purposes.
Step Action: I am viewing an audit history report. | I want to export the audit history.
Step Expected: The system allows me to export the audit history in a standard format (e.g., CSV, Excel).

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the system to track the addition of new documents to a patient's record, so that I can maintain an accurate and auditable history of patient information.
Step Action: A Doctor is viewing a patient's record. | A new document is added to the patient's record.
Step Expected: The system should record the addition of the document, including the user who added it and the timestamp.

Test Case Title: As a Facilitator, I want to be able to track changes to existing documents or data, so that I can maintain an audit trail and ensure data integrity.
Step Action: I am a Facilitator with access to the system. | I make a change to an existing document or data.
Step Expected: The system should record the change, including who made the change and when it was made.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want the system to track deletions of existing documents or data, so that there is an audit trail for data integrity and compliance.
Step Action: a document or data exists in the system | a Clinician deletes the document or data
Step Expected: the system records the deletion event, including the user, timestamp, and details of the deleted item

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to view reports showing auditing history per patient, so that I can track changes to patient data and ensure data integrity.
Step Action: I am logged in as a Doctor. | I request an audit history report for a specific patient.
Step Expected: I should see a report detailing all additions, changes, and deletions made to the patient's documents and data, including the user who made the changes and the timestamp of the changes.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to view the audit history of a document so that I can track changes and ensure data integrity.
Step Action: I am logged in as a Clinician and viewing a patient's document | I select the option to view audit history
Step Expected: I should see a chronological list of all changes made to the document, including who made the change and when.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to view the audit history of a document so that I can track changes and ensure data integrity.
Step Action: I am viewing the audit history of a document | I request to export the audit history
Step Expected: The system should generate a report of the audit history in a standard format (e.g., CSV, PDF) that I can save or print. (Requirement 2.3.3.16)

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to clearly see the link between patient goals and sessions, so that I can better understand the patient's progress and tailor treatment plans effectively.
Step Action: A patient has defined goals and is participating in sessions. | I view the patient's session details in the portal.
Step Expected: I can clearly see how the session relates to the patient's defined goals.

Test Case Title: As a Facilitator, I want to confirm session attendance taken through fingerprint scanner, so that I can ensure accurate records are maintained.
Step Action: I am a facilitator with read access to session attendance data. | I access the system to view session attendance.
Step Expected: I can confirm the attendance taken through the fingerprint scanner is accurate.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to have read access to all documents and write access upon creation or special cases, so that I can view, interpret, create, and add new documents for patient care.
Step Action: I am logged in as a Clinician. | I attempt to access a patient document.
Step Expected: I should be able to view the document.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to have read access to all documents and write access upon creation or special cases, so that I can view, interpret, create, and add new documents for patient care.
Step Action: I am logged in as a Clinician. | I create a new patient document or a special case allows write access.
Step Expected: I should be able to save the document.

Test Case Title: As a System Administrator, I want a database schema and setup guide so that I can properly install and maintain the database.
Step Action: I am a system administrator responsible for database setup and maintenance. | I access the user documentation.
Step Expected: I can view a clear and comprehensive database schema.

Test Case Title: As a System Administrator, I want a database schema and setup guide so that I can properly install and maintain the database.
Step Action: I am a system administrator responsible for database setup and maintenance. | I access the user documentation.
Step Expected: I can follow a step-by-step guide for running the database setup script.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, Nurse, or Patient, I want tutorial documentation within the application so that I can easily learn how to use the system and understand proper procedures.
Step Action: I am a new user of the application. | I access a feature for the first time.
Step Expected: I am presented with step-by-step instructions, screenshots, and in-application tooltips to guide me through the process.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, Nurse, or Patient, I want tutorial documentation within the application so that I can easily learn how to use the system and understand proper procedures.
Step Action: I need to understand a specific procedure. | I access the tutorial documentation.
Step Expected: I can find clear explanations of the procedure, including legal and business concerns, presented in a step-by-step format with visual aids.

Test Case Title: As a Facilitator, I want clear navigation and tooltips in the session application so that I can easily record attendance and take notes.
Step Action: I am a new facilitator using the session application. | I navigate the application.
Step Expected: I can easily understand the purpose of each section due to clear navigation and tooltips.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to view patient assessments and care plans within the Day Health Manager, so that I can efficiently review patient information and provide appropriate care.
Step Action: I am a Doctor with access to the Day Health Manager. | I select a patient within the system.
Step Expected: I can view the patient's digitized assessments and care plans.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to access patient information through the Clinician Portal so that I can quickly review patient data and make informed decisions.
Step Action: I am a Doctor logged into the Clinician Portal. | I navigate to a patient's record.
Step Expected: I should be able to view the patient's relevant medical information in an easy-to-navigate interface.

Test Case Title: As a Facilitator, I want to confirm session attendance taken through fingerprint scanner, so that I can ensure accurate attendance records.
Step Action: the session application has recorded attendance via fingerprint scanner | I access the session attendance records
Step Expected: I can view and confirm the attendance data captured by the fingerprint scanner.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician Portal User, I want the application to respond quickly, so that I can efficiently access and modify patient information.
Step Action: I am a user accessing the Clinician Portal | I navigate to a page within the application
Step Expected: the page loads in under 2 seconds with only one user online

Test Case Title: As a Clinician Portal User, I want the application to respond quickly, so that I can efficiently access and modify patient information.
Step Action: I am a user accessing the Clinician Portal | I navigate to a page within the application
Step Expected: on average the page loads in under 0.5 seconds with only one user online

Test Case Title: As a Clinician Portal User, I want the application to respond quickly, so that I can efficiently access and modify patient information.
Step Action: I am a user accessing the Clinician Portal | I navigate to a page within the application
Step Expected: the page never takes more than 5 seconds to load

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician Portal to load quickly, so that I can efficiently review patient data.
Step Action: I am a Doctor using the Clinician Portal | I access a page within the portal
Step Expected: the page loads in under 2 seconds

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician Portal to load quickly, so that I can efficiently review patient data.
Step Action: I am a Doctor using the Clinician Portal | I access a page within the portal
Step Expected: on average, the page loads in under 0.5 seconds

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want database queries to execute quickly so that I can efficiently access patient information.
Step Action: the system has fewer than 25 active database connections | I execute a database query
Step Expected: the query completes in less than 10 seconds

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician Portal to load quickly so that I can efficiently access patient information.
Step Action: I am a Doctor accessing the Clinician Portal | I navigate to a page within the portal
Step Expected: the page loads in under 2 seconds with one user online.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician Portal to load quickly so that I can efficiently access patient information.
Step Action: I am a Doctor accessing the Clinician Portal | I navigate to a page within the portal
Step Expected: the page loads on average in under 0.5 seconds with one user online.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician Portal to load quickly so that I can efficiently access patient information.
Step Action: I am a Doctor accessing the Clinician Portal | I navigate to a page within the portal
Step Expected: the page never takes more than 5 seconds to load.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician Portal pages to load quickly, so that I can efficiently access patient information and provide timely care.
Step Action: I am a Doctor using the Clinician Portal with only one user online | I access a page within the portal
Step Expected: the page loads in less than 2 seconds

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician Portal pages to load quickly, so that I can efficiently access patient information.
Step Action: I am a Doctor using the Clinician Portal with only one user online | I access a page within the portal
Step Expected: the page should load in under 0.5 seconds on average

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician Portal pages to load quickly, so that I can efficiently review patient data.
Step Action: I am a Doctor using the Clinician Portal | I access a page within the portal
Step Expected: the page loads in under 5 seconds

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want fingerprint scanning to return results quickly, so that I can efficiently access the system.
Step Action: the clinician is using the fingerprint scanner | the clinician initiates a fingerprint scan
Step Expected: the system returns results within 1 second

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the application to load quickly, so that I can efficiently review patient data.
Step Action: I am a Doctor accessing the application | I navigate to a patient's record
Step Expected: the page loads in under 2 seconds

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the application to load quickly, so that I can efficiently review patient data.
Step Action: I am a Doctor accessing the application | I navigate to a patient's record
Step Expected: the page loads on average in under 0.5 seconds

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the application to load quickly, so that I can efficiently review patient data.
Step Action: I am a Doctor accessing the application | I navigate to a patient's record
Step Expected: the page never takes more than 5 seconds to load

Test Case Title: As a Clinician Application, I want to ensure patient information is only accessible to authorized users, so that patient privacy is maintained and HIPAA regulations are met.
Step Action: A user attempts to access patient information | The user is not authorized to view the patient's information
Step Expected: The application will prevent the user from accessing the information

Test Case Title: As a System Administrator, I want the database to be encrypted at rest so that patient data is protected and compliant with HIPAA.
Step Action: The system is deployed and running | Data is stored in the database
Step Expected: The database is encrypted at rest

Test Case Title: As a Clinician Portal user, I want all data transfers to be secured with SSL, so that patient data is protected during transmission.
Step Action: I am a user of the Clinician Portal. | I access or modify any information in the database.
Step Expected: All data transfer between the server and the database is done over an SSL connection.

Test Case Title: As a System Administrator, I want the database to only be accessible by devices on the same network so that patient data is protected and complies with HIPAA.
Step Action: The system is deployed in a network environment | A device attempts to connect to the database from outside the designated network
Step Expected: The connection is refused and an error message is logged.

Test Case Title: As a System Administrator, I want the database to only be accessible by devices on the same network so that patient data is protected and complies with HIPAA.
Step Action: A device is on the same network as the database | The device attempts to connect to the database
Step Expected: The connection is established successfully.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want all communication between the server and Clinician Application to be done over SSL, so that patient data is secure and complies with HIPAA.
Step Action: I am a Doctor using the Clinician Application | I am accessing or modifying patient information
Step Expected: all communication between the server and the Clinician Application is encrypted using SSL.

Test Case Title: As a Session App User, I want all patient information stored locally on the computer to be encrypted so that patient data is protected and compliant with HIPAA.
Step Action: The session app is running on a computer. | Patient information is stored locally on the computer.
Step Expected: The patient information is encrypted.

Test Case Title: As a Session App, I want all communication with the server to be done over SSL so that patient information stored locally is secure.
Step Action: The Session App is communicating with the server | Data is being transmitted between the Session App and the server
Step Expected: The communication must be encrypted using SSL

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician Application to have a high aesthetic rating, so that I find it visually appealing and easy to use.
Step Action: The Clinician Application is being used by a Doctor. | The Doctor interacts with the application's user interface.
Step Expected: The Doctor should rate the application's aesthetics at 4/5 or higher.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician application to be easy to use so that I can efficiently review patient data.
Step Action: I am a Doctor using the Clinician application. | I am performing common tasks such as reviewing patient data.
Step Expected: The application should be intuitive and easy to navigate, allowing me to complete my tasks efficiently.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician application to be easy to learn so that I can quickly access and interpret patient data.
Step Action: I am a Doctor using the Clinician application for the first time. | I attempt to navigate the application and access patient data.
Step Expected: The application should be intuitive and easy to understand, allowing me to quickly find the information I need.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician application to be easy to learn so that I can quickly access and interpret patient data.
Step Action: 90% of Doctors are using the Clinician application. | They are asked to rate the application for ease of learning.
Step Expected: At least 90% of Doctors should rate the application at ⅘ or above for ease of learning.

Test Case Title: As a Facilitator, I want the Session App to have an appealing aesthetic so that I can effectively engage users during sessions.
Step Action: the user is a facilitator using the Session App | they interact with the application's user interface
Step Expected: the application's aesthetic is rated at 4/5 or above by at least 85% of facilitators.

Test Case Title: As a Facilitator, I want the Session App to be easy to learn so that I can quickly and effectively use it to manage sessions.
Step Action: The facilitator is a new user of the Session App. | The facilitator completes the initial training and uses the app for a few sessions.
Step Expected: The facilitator rates the Session App at ⅘ or above for ease of learning.

Test Case Title: As a Facilitator, I want the Session App to be easy to learn so that I can quickly and effectively use it to manage sessions.
Step Action: A survey is conducted with facilitators after using the Session App. | The survey results are analyzed.
Step Expected: At least 90% of facilitators rate the Session App at ⅘ or above for ease of learning.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to use the Clinician Portal so that I can easily review patient data within the EHR.
Step Action: I am a Doctor logged into the Clinician Portal | I access a patient's record

Step Expected: I should see a report showing additions, changes, and deletions of documents and data, per user and per patient.

Step Expected: The system should allow me to export the auditing history.
